captions.text:
l used to drag here
back in high school.

That railroad crossing up there is
exactly a quarter mile away from here.
On green, l'm going for it.

comments.text:
+Joseph Ahmed I did come here after watching Furious 7, but just to remind 
myself why I cared about Fast and the Furious franchise in the first place. 
Holy shit I was so incredibly disapointed in Furious 7, I heard so many 
good things about it, yet to me it was the most generic, mindless, 
unrelated bunch of action scenes ever, stringed together by the thinnest 
plot I've ever seen. I liked the series when it was about fast cars and 
insane races, but Furious 7 could honestly be a generic Stallone action 
movie, what the hell was The Rock doing with a mini-gun in that movie, 
jesus christ

comments.text:
So Brian is meant to be driving Dom's 10 second car, yet in this piece of 
film it takes a minute to cover that distance, and the distance shown 
before they take off at the lights is dramatically shorter than it is 
exaggerated in this clip. Also, why would the light go green just as the 
train needs access to the crossing? - isn't it somebody's job to coordinate 
that sh*t a little better?﻿

comments.text:
One of the best movie scenes ever...! ;)

I really hope the final race between Brain & Dom in Furious 7 (white Supra 
vs. grey Charger) will be kind of a remake of this one from the first 
movie! (but without the crash of course)
It would be amazing, a legendary throwback and honor to Paul Walker... ﻿
comments.author: Kev27RS

comments.text: i think that's the scene that was cancelled
comments.author: Josh Edillon

comments.text:
Yes the one in the first movie and also in 7 is gloss black, but the one 
which can be seen in one of the last TV spots of Furious 7 at the end, is 
grey! ;)
For the part..why the Supra? Well, I think it's to remember the last race 
of the first F&F (in this video above) and because it was the first race 
between Dom & Brian alone... ;) 

So, in Furious 7 there are going to be two Charger's, the legendary black 
one, and another in grey.

Real Fact:  The white Supra (can also be seen in the same short seconds 
scene where the grey Charger appears) was actually Paul Walker's real car, 
it was one of his car collection that he had!
comments.author: Kev27RS

comments.text:
just as a note the charger would have to have rolled forward before it 
could do a wheelie. and my family own a 1970 charger r/t and let me tell 
you even with 900 horsepower the car would have to have alot of work and 
weight reduction before it could keep its front of the ground.﻿
comments.author: glatic storm

comments.text:
they used a ram full of compressed air to launch the car up. wheelies are 
possible in these cars but they have to have drastic weight reduction,rear 
wheel drive and a heavly modified engine. (like the car in the film) 
however doing this would destroy an awesome car and you wouldnt be able to 
drive it on a normal road.
